newsitem.title: USA: Brady market soporific as all eyes watching U.S.
newsitem.headline: Brady market soporific as all eyes watching U.S.

text.p: Emerging market debt prices were confined to narrow ranges Wednesday as liquidity dried up ahead of the U.S. payrolls report on Friday, traders said.
"In Latins there is nothing going on except trading along with Treasuries," one Brady bond trader said. "Everyone is waiting until Friday."
But the Brady market held on to its gains as the U.S. long bond closed 1/2 point lower to yield 7.10 percent.
Brady traders also offered little reaction to confirmation that Argentine government was exploring options for issuing a 30-year bond, perhaps as a global bond.
Another financing option would be to reopen the 20 year 350 million mark Eurobond launched on Tuesday, an Argentine official said.
Argentine FRBs picked up 1/4 for a bid price of 79, while discounts were unchanged 69-1/8.
Walter Molano, director of Latin American Research at Swiss Bank, said he anticipated FRBs would maintain a strong bid tone as the stock of paper declines.
"They have been resilient to volatility in the region and in the country," Molano said.
As countries develop their own capital markets and start buying back their Brady debt, the emerging debt markets would likely perform much more smoothly, Molano said.

Some Wall Street bankers may not be warming to the prospect of diminished Brady liquidity, but the trend of refinancing could only be positive for Argentina, said one analyst at a major U.S. pension fund.
"As trader you may not like it, but from a fundamental point of view it is definitely good news," the analyst said.

"The bottom line is that the country needs financing and the longer term financing it can raise the better," the analyst said. "From a debt management point-of-view it would be the right thing to do."
